feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 03 at 2:33AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Another round of snow for the Interior on Tuesday... Another round of snow showers is expected acros the Central Interior this morning and continuing into the afternoon. Snowfall totals of around 1 to 2 inches is expected for many locations. Heavy snow showers could reduce visibility at times. Please plan ahead for slippery road conditions and use caution when traveling.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Interior; Chatanika River Valley; Delta Junction; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Fairbanks Metro Area; Fortymile Country; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Tanana Flats; Two Rivers; Upper Chena River Valley; Upper Tanana Valley; White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 03 at 4:16AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: Patchy dense fog in and near river and valley locations in southwest Connecticut and the lower Hudson valley will reduce visibilities to 1/4 mile or less. The fog should dissipate by 10 AM. Motorists in these areas need to be especially alert to rapidly changing visibilities. Use your low beam headlights or fog lamps,

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 03 at 9:07AM EDT until further notice by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida... St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties. .Recent heavy rainfall over or upstream from Astor, combined with northeast winds and high astronomical tides, have brought the Saint Johns River at Astor to Moderate Flood Stage. River levels are forecast to remain just above Moderate Flood Stage

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 03 at 6:42AM EDT until further notice by NWS
entry.summary: ...Forecast flooding changed to Minor severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Florida... Fisheating Creek near Palmdale affecting Glades County. For the Fisheating Creek...including Palmdale...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE...

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 03 at 6:31AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WET SNOW WILL AFFECT THE BIGHORN MOUNTAINS THIS MORNING... Heavy wet snow showers are impacting the Bighorn Mountains this morning, with a snow level at approximately 7500 feet. Travelers on Highway 14 through Burgess Junction should be prepared to encounter slushy and potentially slick roads, and poor visibility. Snow accumulation of 1 to 4 inches is expected over the higher elevations.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 03 at 6:12AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Areas of dense fog early this morning... Please watch for areas of dense fog, with visibilities at or below one-quarter of a mile, through 8 AM. If you are driving and encounter dense fog, please slow down, use your low beam headlights and allow for some extra travel time to safely reach your destination.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 03 at 4:46AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...LOCALIZED DENSE FOG AROUND CHEYENNE EARLY THIS MORNING... Fog has developed early this morning around the Cheyenne area with visibilities reduced down to one quarter mile at times. This area of fog is expected to linger through sunrise, mainly between Mile Markers 350 and 375 along Interstate 80, and between the Colorado border and Mile Marker 20 along Interstate 25.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Laramie County; South Laramie Range Foothills

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 02 at 2:29PM MDT until October 03 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 6 PM MDT TUESDAY... * WHAT...Snow expected, mainly above 8,000 feet. Snow accumulation will vary greatly with elevation. Generally 3 to 6 inches between 8,500 feet and 9,500 feet. Higher amounts over a foot possible above 10,000 feet.
